Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Nonlinear Design and Development of Multi Degree-of-freedom Broadband Energy Harvesting Systems

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project addresses the harvesting and conversion of mechanical energy from low-level ambient vibration into usable electrical energy. Utilizing the unique properties of "essentially" nonlinear vibrating systems, it develops multi degree-of-freedom, passive, broadband devices that will increase the efficiency and performance of energy harvesting systems acting on low-level ambient vibrations. Three research tasks are undertaken: 1) analysis of the system-level dynamics including nonlinearity in both the mechanical resonator and the electrical charging system; 2) design and application of multidegree-of-freedom resonators to enhance harvesting; and 3) experimental verification of proposed designs. Furthermore, collaboration with a group at the University of Bristol (UK) seeks to incorporate state of the art energy conversion strategies that can work efficiently in conjunction with the broadband resonator to produce a reliable, consistent source of power.

The research is anticipated to lead to an enabling technology for next-generation portable devices and wireless sensors and provide a novel framework for the design and optimization of systems that incorporate nonlinear elements. Finally, this project enhances the diversity of the engineering community through targeted outreach, undergraduate research programs, and the support of students from underrepresented groups.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Energy harvesting describes the conversion of mechanical vibrational energy that nominally exists in the world around us into electrical energy that can subsequently be used to power devices, thus providing a self-renewing power source and recovering energy that would otherwise be wasted. This project extended the envelope of such devices to incorporate systems that were essentially nonlinear by design, and thus were able to show increased efficiency and performance of energy harvesting systems to low-level ambient vibrations.

In collaboration with researchers at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, this project considered the performance of such systems through a combined analytical, numerical, and experimental approach, and was able to identify the underlying mechanisms that enable efficient harvesting in such systems. Specifically, transient resonance capture describes the observed phenomena whereby energy can be readily transfered from a primary system, such as an engineering structure, to the energy harvesting component and then into the electrical domain. Transient resonance capture is characterized by large-amplitude motion of the secondary harvesting component whose frequency coincides with that of the primary system.

Essentially nonlinear systems have no single preferential frequency of oscillation. Instead, their resonant frequency depends on their amplitude of motion, and can span a wide range of frequencies. It is this characteristic that gives rise to efficient harvesting in environments where the frequency of the excitation can vary. In contrast, linear systems possess a single resonant frequency and only respond efficiently if tuned to the vibration source. Thus, in broadband or non-stationary environments where tuning is not possible, we have illustrated efficient harvesting using our approach based on essentially nonlinear components.

Based on our combined approach, detailed models of an energy harvesting system were formulated to account for the response of the primary engineering system and the nonlinear energy harvester, together with the electromechanical coupling and the accompanying electrical circuit. Exhaustive numerical simulations were performed on this system to identify design and parametric values leading to efficient harvesting. From this, reduced-order modes were developed based on the method of averaging and these were studied to uncover the dynamic mechanisms in the system response underlying the identified transient resonance capture. As illustrated in the accompanying figures, the numerical response of the detailed system, shown in light blue is closely follows the predictions of the analytical system shown in black. Finally, experimental studies at UIUC together with detailed parametric identification were carried out to validate and verify the numerical and analytical findings.

The broader impact of this project is three-fold. This work has considered a novel design class of systems that can possibly be used to extend the concept of energy harvesting to ambient vibration environments in which linear devices have been shown to not operate efficiently. Second, the general framework of this research project has illustrated how mechanical systems can be designed to not only incorporate, but to take advantage of the unique properties held by essentially nonlinear systems. Finally, this project has trained students, both at the graduate and undergraduate levels, and has enhanced the diversity of the engineering community through outreach and by incorporating female students into the supported activities.
